workflow.description:
Run a script inside the VM and wait until it returns his result. Retrieve the output of the script and returns it as output in the workflow
Inspired by implementation done in PowerCLI in the following .NET class : - VMware.VimAutomation.ViCore.Impl.V1.RunScriptInGuestHelper - VMware.VimAutomation.ViCore.Impl.V1.Service.VmGuestServiceImpl
Requires running VMwareTools instance in the GuestOS. Leverages the vSphere 5.x GuestOperationsManager object and is not backwards compatible with previous versions of vSphere.

param.name: scriptTimeout
param.description: Timeout for the running script (in second)

param.name: scriptRefreshTime
param.description: (default) Time (in seconds) where a check of script status occurs

param.name: scriptWorkingDirectory
param.description: Script working directory in the guest

attrib.name: scriptPid
attrib.description: (internal) Pid of the script cmd in the guest

attrib.name: scriptProcessInfo
attrib.description: (internal) List of running processes in the guest

attrib.name: scriptOutputFile
attrib.description: (internal) File path where the script output will be written in the guest

attrib.name: scriptOutputPrefix
attrib.description: (default) The prefix to be given to the new temporary file

attrib.name: vcoCopiedFileResult
attrib.description: (internal) True if copy operation was successful

attrib.name: cmdAnsi
attrib.description: Redirects cmd output to ANSI. Thanks to Pierre Torris www.ptorris.com

attrib.name: powershellScriptGuestPath
attrib.description: The absolute path of the temporary file that is created.

attrib.name: powershellSuffix
attrib.description: The suffix to be given to the new temporary file

attrib.name: guestTempDirectory
attrib.description: The absolute path of the temporary directory that is created.

item3
workflow-item.script: if(scriptType.toLowerCase() == "bash") return true; return false;

workflow-item.script: return System.getModule("com.vmware.pso.GuestOps").testVmToolsForGuestOps(vm);

workflow-item.name: item14
workflow-item.script: //Generated by the system, cannot be edited return (scriptFinished == true) ;

workflow-item.name: item16
item18
workflow-item.script: return (scriptTimeout > scriptTimeoutCounter*scriptRefreshTime)

workflow-item.name: item21
workflow-item.description: Use the same implementation as used in PowerCLI (VMware.VimAutomation.ViCore.Impl.V1.RunScriptInGuestHelper)

workflow-item.name: item11
item17

bind.name: dirPath
bind.description: The complete path to the directory in which to create the new file. If unset or an empty string, a guest-specific location will be used.

bind.name: prefix
bind.description: The prefix to be given to the new temporary file

bind.name: suffix
bind.description: The suffix to be given to the new temporary file

bind.name: result
bind.description: The absolute path of the temporary file that is created.

workflow-item.description: Create a temporary file in a guest virtual machine.

workflow-item.name: item0

bind.name: interactiveSession
bind.description: This is set to true if the client wants an interactive session in the guest.

bind.name: programPath
bind.description: The absolute path to the program to start. For Linux guest operating systems, /bin/bash is used to start the program. For Solaris guest operating systems, /bin/bash is used to start the program if it exists. Otherwise /bin/sh is used. If /bin/sh is used, then the process ID returned will be that of the shell used to start the program, rather than the program itself, due to the differences in how /bin/sh and /bin/bash work. This PID will still be usable for watching the process with this API to find its exit code and elapsed time.

bind.name: arguments
bind.description: The arguments to the program. In Linux and Solaris guest operating systems, the program will be executed by a guest shell. This allows stdio redirection, but may also require that characters which must be escaped to the shell also be escaped on the command line provided. For Windows guest operating systems, prefixing the command with "cmd /c" can provide stdio redirection.

bind.name: workingDirectory
bind.description: The absolute path of the working directory for the program to be run. VMware recommends explicitly setting the working directory for the program to be run. If this value is unset or is an empty string, the behavior depends on the guest operating system. For Linux guest operating systems, if this value is unset or is an empty string, the working directory will be the home directory of the user associated with the guest authentication. For other guest operating systems, if this value is unset, the behavior is unspecified.

bind.name: environment
bind.description: An array of environment variables, specified in the guest OS notation (eg PATH=c:\bin;c:\windows\system32 or LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/lib:/lib), to be set for the program being run. Note that these are not additions to the default environment variables; they define the complete set available to the program. If none are specified the values are guest dependent.

bind.name: result
bind.description: The pid of the program started.

workflow-item.description: Starts a program in the guest operating system. A process started this way can have its status queried with this API. When the process completes, its exit code and end time will be available for 5 minutes after completion.

workflow-item.name: item1
workflow-item.description: List the processes running in the guest operating system, plus those started by this API that have recently completed

workflow-item.name: item4

bind.name: result
bind.description: Set to true if copy operation was successful

workflow-item.description: Copies the specified file from the guest filesystem to the vCO server.

workflow-item.name: item2

bind.name: pid
bind.description: Process ID of the process to be terminated

workflow-item.description: Terminates a process in the guest OS.

workflow-item.name: item12
item15
workflow-item.script: if(scriptType.toLowerCase() == "batch" || scriptType.toLowerCase() == "bat") return true; return false;

workflow-item.name: item20
workflow-item.script: if(scriptType.toLowerCase() == "powershell") return true; return false;

workflow-item.name: item19
workflow-item.script: errorMessage = "VMware Tools are not running"

workflow-item.name: item22
workflow-item.script: errorMessage = "Script Type doesn't match with 'batch' / 'powershell' / 'bash'"

workflow-item.name: item23
workflow-item.description: Use the same implementation as used in PowerCLI (VMware.VimAutomation.ViCore.Impl.V1.RunScriptInGuestHelper)

workflow-item.name: item24
workflow-item.script: System.warn("Script timeout - process has been killed");

workflow-item.description: Create temporary file on vCO server

workflow-item.name: item28

bind.name: result
bind.description: Set to true if copy operation was successful

workflow-item.description: Copy cmdAnsi from vCO to guest

workflow-item.name: item30
item32
workflow-item.script: cmdAnsiGuestPath = guestTempDirectory+"\\"+cmdAnsi.name;

workflow-item.name: item26
workflow-item.script: //Generated by the system, cannot be edited return (useCmdAnsi == true) ;

workflow-item.name: item27
workflow-item.script: scriptProgramPath = "cmd.exe"; scriptArguments = "/A /C type " + scriptOutputFile + " | cmdansi " + scriptOutputFile;

workflow-item.name: item29

bind.name: interactiveSession

bind.name: programPath
bind.description: The absolute path to the program to start. For Linux guest operating systems, /bin/bash is used to start the program. For Solaris guest operating systems, /bin/bash is used to start the program if it exists. Otherwise /bin/sh is used. If /bin/sh is used, then the process ID returned will be that of the shell used to start the program, rather than the program itself, due to the differences in how /bin/sh and /bin/bash work. This PID will still be usable for watching the process with this API to find its exit code and elapsed time.

bind.name: arguments

This allows stdio redirection, but may also require that characters which must be escaped to the shell also be escaped on the command line provided. For Windows guest operating systems, prefixing the command with "cmd /c" can provide stdio redirection.

bind.name: workingDirectory
bind.description: The absolute path of the working directory for the program to be run. VMware recommends explicitly setting the working directory for the program to be run. If this value is unset or is an empty string, the behavior depends on the guest operating system. For Linux guest operating systems, if this value is unset or is an empty string, the working directory will be the home directory of the user associated with the guest authentication. Note that these are not additions to the default environment variables; they define the complete set available to the program. If none are specified the values are guest dependent.
